comments.commentBody:
We allow a Policeman to "shoot to kill" when a criminal starts shooting at him.

We allow/expect the Police to kill a gunman who has and is full intent on
killing more people in a public space.

However, if a person is duly and honestly/truly convicted of murder - we
are expected to just lock them away for the rest of their life...

Does anyone doubt that the young man in Connecticut killed his parents this past Summer and that his girlfriend assisted him ? There will be a trial and he
will be convicted, she, if she is smart, will 'Plea-Bargain' her way to 15 - 20 years in Prison - out in 8 years - while he is sentenced to 'Life in Prison'

Because our Judicial System is anything but Just - and because it seems
ir-reformable - what else can the Supreme Court due but find the application of
the Death Penalty to be cruel...

GMooG:

I didn't assert "immense support" for doing away with the death penalty, I acknowledged the left's CLAIM of that support.

Steve:

The founders were quite split on slavery, or I read my John Adams very wrong. They compromised on slavery so that we could have a nation and a constitution, because without those compromises there would have been neither.

The world changes all the time, and we can even change the text of the Constitution whenever we want. But let's do it by statutes that interpret the Constitution when that's allowed or amendments when it's not -- and that's the role of Congress, whose members we elect, not of our federal courts, whose judges we don't.

The death penalty has its origins long before the colonization of the American continents, and long before the enslavement of the African peoples was ever considered. Further to your comment, Kennedy v. Louisiana established conclusively that the death penalty could not be applied even for the most heinous offenses of child rape, unless the crime intended or resulted in the death of the victim.

Your attempts to link the death penalty with slavery seem to indicate the paucity of your possessing any real arguments against it.

Cynthia - I agree, if people would just stop murdering each other we would eliminate the death penalty since there would be no need for it, so let's just stop ALL the killing, not just killing the guilty.

The contact information for "Couch" editors is posted with every essay.  I certainly hope that if they get more submissions from patients who have not benefited from therapy, they would post those, too.  If only practitioners post essays, extolling their own contributions, then that's all that will get published.

Thanks so much David, I appreciate your time. Yes, you are so right, the picture presented here, is that it is always works out, like a magic. But, many of us who have been there for years, know the truth-- it really works out for the therapist's bank account!

So I must applaud this comment and thus must copy it and post it again:
"There is a pay off but it's usually not for the benefit of the patient. Indeed the author here basically admits that she withheld needed help until she was about to be dumped and her income stream terminated. And then it's the patient's responsibility to provide the therapist with reassurances abut what has been accomplished and "edification" for the future. A shameful scam."

I totally agree with this writer and I couldn't write it more accurately!
I want to share my private story as a patient who was abused by a pathological narccisitic therapist. To share something about this fake dyad from a patient's perspective and I really think it will help others who are treated by unqualified therapists who abuse their fragile state and emotionally exploit them.
Can someone advise me how I can do it? Can I publish it here in this frame? With whom should I contact? I will appreciate your help! My wound is still open and I want to help others.

And you thought Chinas would be honest?

Just like the Japanese who don't respect whaling quotas and international agreements, we have the Chinese who don't respect carbon imprint quotas.

America always "supposedly" places by the rules, but others don't. Can you say Kissinger and the Vietnam Paris peace accord in 1 breath?
Perhaps Bo Derek made a splash not because of her cornrows, but because she played a libertine character who had sex with a middle-aged guy.

If you don't grasp the difference between Bo and 99.99% of other women - black, brown and white - I can't explain it to you.

Hint: it is not "coolness"
It was really the scene where Dudley Moore has to keep restarting the record for "Bolero" that made the splash, the braids weren't the big deal.

As a black woman I do not mind when white women wear cornrows. I think the problem is that white women tend to get more attention than we do when they appropriate black culture. I remember when Bo Derek wore braids. She made a splash. Where was the high regard for all the sistas who had been wearing them for eternity? Why did it need a white woman to make people realise how cool braids are?
Some guys look great with pony tails--think Adrian Paul in his Highlander days--and others just look dorky or unkempt.  But, man buns?  They don't look good on anyone.  Ugh!
why do you care about others saying that your hair is beautiful? It's how you feel about it what counts.

I think the point the other comments are missing is that when cornrows, or other clearly African-American hairstyles like twists, are worn on black girls and women they are a source of derision.  There is no doubt that on black females these stereotypical hairstyles are considered unsophisticated.  But when they are worn by beautiful white women they are a sign of style, cutting-edge fashion, and beauty.  The frustration the author feels is palpable because it is real.  Yes, anyone can wear their hair any way they want.  But why is it avant-garde only when white women do it?  That's complicated in ways the comments do not appreciate or respect.  Imagine being that little girl made fun of for your hair.  No one ever tells you it is beautiful.  Only later, and only when white women are wearing cornrows, do they become "beautiful."  Of course that stings.  Of course.

and Elke
Kiki- think of Galina in a TUTU......
PS- is your avatar a SNEETCH ?
No, the argument is that there is a double standard. redsquirrel NY, above, explains it very well.
No St. Patrick's Day.  No Cinco de Mayo.

It only requires some time to consider the nature of human culture throughout history to understand why this sort of outrage is utterly misguided. The argument seems to be that because cornrows are so closely associated with African culture, they ought to be restricted to African Americans in the United States.

If we followed that logic, then white people wouldn't be allowed to play banjos, write or play jazz or blues or rock-and-roll. Dance styles would have to go back a hundred years. White people could only paint pictures of other whites. Black authors would have to write with black audiences in mind, and wouldn't be allowed to play roles in movies, television, or theater that might otherwise have been played by whites. The logic that elements of black culture are only for black people suggests that white culture is only for white people. It's a call for cultural segregation.

I wonder what our civilization would be like if people simply rejected foreign customs and traditions for no better reason than their foreignness. If Europe, and then America, hadn't looked to Roman culture for ideas of government and social institutions, or to China and India for goods that transformed everyday life. If Rome hadn't tried to emulate Greek culture. If we'd rejected agriculture because it was too Sumerian.

Maybe it's a one-way street; minorities can adopt the customs of other cultures, but shouldn't transmit their own. That's a recipe for cultural extinction.

"Never mind that jazz as an art form was supported mainly by whites."
Sir, you are dead wrong. By that statement one can only assume you know few blacks. To give whites credit for being the ones that mostly supported jazz, is just plain ignorant and on a deeper level, offensive.
Whites loudly rally against racism while appropriating black culture. That's fine. The problem is, whites largely accept, appreciate and appropriate black culture, but not the people. How many black women have been in Vogue magazine wearing cornrows? How many black women have been in Vogue, period? How many blacks does Valentino, or any other haute couture house appoint to top executive positions? Take a look at NYTimes style magazine and count how many ads feature any black people. Take a look at any glossy magazine(save for black magazines) and count how many blacks you see in the pages.
I believe the flash of annoyance Ms. Arterbery experiences stems from the knowledge that white society will by and large accept and appreciate her cornrows, but not her.

I think a lot of the underlying point that everyone is missing in the comments is that the author was made fun of for her hair growing up - it would be painful, or irritating for anyone who had been criticized by a certain group to later see that group embracing / celebrating what they previously made fun of. I know it would be for me.

With that said, I hope that we all can get to the point soon where we realize that America is a melting pot of cultures (and the better for us) and we've all borrowed from all other groups - how about pizza, sausages, corned beef, tartan clothing, stir-fry, burritos, etc. All of "white" culture, and every other culture that has come to America, has been consumed by all people in this country. There are no dividing lines really, and if we seek to invent them, or start drawing lines between what is mine and what is yours we'll be hurting ourselves in the long run. Our strength in the future will only be possible if we can unite as one people.
Really?  All white Americans?  Quite an offensive generalization.

Bob O, was that a question, like " . . . can we spend our time on more significant issues than hair styles?"

One word: No! Or two words: Apparently not . . .
Why can't it be taken as a compliment? My mom always told me that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.

Four words: Eurocentric values of beauty.
Two more words: White Supremacy.
At the risk of just about everything, reads like women talking about women's things with a chorus line of PC thrown in,  but it sure beats war.
Using instruments invented by Europeans. Now what?
Take a look at some Neolithic "Venus" figurines found in Europe. Modern cornrows may have their roots in Africa, but women outside of Africa were wearing them thousands of years ago.
I thought Bo Derek owned it?

What about blond, straight haired Beyoncé ? Is that not appropriation of white standards of beauty? This appropriation thing is absurd.  I thought wet wanted integration of the races, not "blacks only" signs on cornrows, for goodness sake.
Everybody wants to be Black until the police arrive.
No!

Not true. You would do yourself and everybody else a favor if you would stop repeating these negative thoughts to yourself. They serve only to embitter you .they are exaggerations designed to maintain a level of hate and distrust alive .
